User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user in the Orin platform.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

StudentProfile.title: StudentProfile
StudentProfile.description: Represents the profile of a student user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the StudentProfile entity.

MentorProfile.title: MentorProfile
MentorProfile.description: Represents the profile of a mentor user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the MentorProfile entity.

Category.title: Category
Category.description: Represents a category for subjects and mentors.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Category entity.

parentCategoryId.description: Reference to parent Category. (Relationship: Category 1:N Category)

Subject.title: Subject
Subject.description: Represents a subject within a category.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Subject entity.

Exam.title: Exam
Exam.description: Represents an exam specification linked to a category.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Exam entity.

MentorExpertise.title: MentorExpertise
MentorExpertise.description: Junction table linking mentors to subjects and exams.

id.description: Unique identifier for the MentorExpertise entity.

MentorCategory.title: MentorCategory
MentorCategory.description: Junction table for mentor category associations.

id.description: Unique identifier for the MentorCategory entity.

TimeSlot.title: TimeSlot
TimeSlot.description: Represents a time slot for mentor availability.

id.description: Unique identifier for the TimeSlot entity.

startTime.description: Start time of the time slot.

endTime.description: End time of the time slot.

bookingStatus.description: Booking status of the time slot (e.g., available, booked).

Booking.title: Booking
Booking.description: Represents a booking made by a student for a mentor's time slot.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Booking entity.

status.description: Status of the booking (e.g., pending, confirmed, completed, cancelled).

Review.title: Review
Review.description: Represents a review given by a student for a mentor.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Review entity.
Unique identifier for the Favorite entity.

ChatMessage.title: ChatMessage
ChatMessage.description: Represents a chat message between a student and a mentor.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ChatMessage entity.

Resource.title: Resource
Resource.description: Represents a resource uploaded by a mentor.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Resource entity.

Transaction.title: Transaction
Transaction.description: Represents a transaction for payment tracking.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Transaction entity.

paymentAmount.description: The amount paid in the transaction.

mentorEarnings.description: Earnings of the mentor after commission.

CouponCode.title: CouponCode
CouponCode.description: Represents a coupon code for discounts.

id.description: Unique identifier for the CouponCode entity.

expiry.description: Expiry date of the coupon code.

usageLimits.description: Usage limits for the coupon code.

Notification.title: Notification
Notification.description: Represents a notification for email/in-app notifications.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Notification entity.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support the Orin platform's mentoring marketplace, focusing on security, scalability, and debuggability. The design adheres to Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), QAPs (Rules are not Filters), and Invariants.

**Authorization Independence:**
Authorization independence is achieved by denormalizing authorization-related data. For example, the `Booking` documents duplicate `studentId` and `mentorId`. This eliminates the need for `get()` calls in security rules to verify user roles or relationships, enabling atomic operations and improving security rule performance.

**Structural Segregation (Homogeneous Security Posture):**
The database structure segregates data based on access needs. User profiles are stored under `/users/{userId}`, ensuring that only the user and admins can access them. Mentor-specific data like `/users/{mentorId}/timeslots` and `/users/{mentorId}/resources` are organized under the mentor's profile, clearly defining ownership and access.

**Access Modeling (Standardization and Consistency):**
The design uses consistent patterns for authorization:

*   **Private Data:** User profiles and related data (student profiles, mentor profiles) are stored using path-based ownership under `/users/{userId}`.
*   **User-Owned Data:** Data related to users such as time slots (`/users/{mentorId}/timeslots/{timeslotId}`), resources (`/users/{mentorId}/resources/{resourceId}`), bookings (`/users/{studentId}/bookings/{bookingId}`) are organized hierarchically.
*   **Collaborative Data:** The chat messages are stored in `/bookings/{bookingId}/chat_messages/{messageId}`, this is fine since a user must have an existing booking to be able to chat, which also creates a paper trail for admins in case of disputes.
*   **Global Roles (DBAC):** While the schema includes a `role` field in the `User` document, it is recommended to manage admin roles via the existence of documents in a dedicated `/roles_admin/{uid}` collection. This simplifies security rules and avoids content-based authorization.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):**
The data structure supports secure `list` operations by avoiding reliance on filtering data based on user roles in the rules. For instance, listing mentors is enabled through `/users/{mentorId}`. If a global list of mentors is required without authentication, a separate collection `/mentors` containing a subset of safe data from `/users/{mentorId}` could be maintained (This would need to be kept in sync via a cloud function on writes to `/users/{mentorId}`).

**Data Clarity and Predictability:**

*   **Explicit State Modeling:** The `Booking` entity has a `status` field that explicitly models the state of a booking (pending, confirmed, completed, cancelled), improving clarity and avoiding complex logic based on multiple fields.
*   **Predictable Schema:** The schema uses static keys and avoids dynamic keys. Arrays of objects are used where applicable.
*   **Radical Consistency:** Naming conventions are standardized, with authorization fields consistently named (e.g., `userId`, `mentorId`, `studentId`).
